keyTakeAways: Coca-Cola has begun selling a soda made with cane sugar instead of high-fructose corn syrup in select U.S. cities and retailers, following a request from President Donald Trump.
This shift aligns with Trump’s advocacy against high-fructose corn syrup, which he criticized through his Health and Human Services secretary, Robert F. Kennedy, Jr.
The move marks a significant policy-driven change in a major food product, reflecting the influence of political leaders on corporate decisions.

While health experts note that sugar-filled sodas are unhealthy regardless of the sweetener used, Coca-Cola is expanding healthier alternatives like Coca-Cola Zero Sugar, which saw a 14% global volume increase and drove a 3% share jump.
The company already uses cane sugar in some U.S. products like Simply Lemonade, Gold Peak iced tea, and Costa canned coffee, demonstrating prior experimentation with natural sweeteners.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Coca-Cola has launched a cane sugar-based soda in select U.S. cities following a request from President Donald Trump, who advocated against high-fructose corn syrup. This shift, supported by Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., reflects broader political and health-related pressure on food production. While health experts note that sugary drinks remain unhealthy regardless of sweetener, the move aligns with Coca-Cola’s larger strategy of promoting healthier alternatives, including the successful growth of its sugar-free Coca-Cola Zero Sugar and relaunched products like BodyArmor and Smartwater.
title: Coca-Cola’s Trump-approved soda begins to roll out in the United States
